javax.realtime
Class GarbageCollector

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--javax.realtime.GarbageCollector
public class GarbageCollector
extends java.lang.Object

The system shall provide information characterizing the behavior of the garbage collection algorithm provided by the system for query by the realtime application. The full set of characterization information has as yet to be defined, but a representative set is given below.

public static final int NOT_APPLICABLE
Constructor Detail

GarbageCollector

public GarbageCollector()
Method Detail

getMaximumReclamationRate

public long getMaximumReclamationRate()
Maximum reclamation rate the garbage collector can sustain. This is a dynamically assigned value dependent on schedule. Return value is measured in kilobytes per second.

getPreemptionLatency

public RelativeTime getPreemptionLatency()
Returns a RelativeTime. Instances of RealtimeThread are allowed to preempt the execution of the garbage collector (NoHeapRealtimeThreads preempt immediately but RealtimeThreads must wait until the collector reaches a preemption-safe point). Preemption latency is a measure of the maximum time a RealtimeThread may have to wait for the collector to reach a preemption-safe point. A return value of null means this measurement is not useful for the implemented garbage collection algorithm.

getReadBarrierOverhead

public int getReadBarrierOverhead()
Overhead of the read barrier. Given in percentage of the cost of a field access. A return value of NOT_APPLICABLE means this measurement is not applicable for the implemented garbage collection algorithm.

getWriteBarrierOverhead

public int getWriteBarrierOverhead()
Overhead of the write barrier. Given in percentage of the cost of an assignment. A return value of NOT_APPLICABLE means this measurement is not applicable for the implemented garbage collection algorithm.

setReclamationRate

public void setReclamationRate(int rate)
The reclamation rate as a ratio: 1 / number of kilobytes scanned per kilobyte allocated. Used by incremental collection algorithms to pace their reclamation rate.
